1848	1	2	This is a digital copy of a book that was preserved for generations on library shelves before it was carefully scanned by Google as part of a project
1848	1	3	10 make the world’s books discoverable online.
1848	1	4	It has survived long enough for the copyright to expire and the book to enter the public domain. A public domain book is one that was never subject
1848	1	5	10 copyright or whose legal copyright term has expired. Whether a book is in the public domain may vary country to country. Public domain books
1848	1	6	are our gateways to the past, representing a wealth of history, culture and knowledge that’s often difficult to discover.
1848	1	7	Marks, notations and other marginalia present in the original volume will appear in this file - a reminder of this book’s long journey from the
1848	1	8	publisher to a library and finally to you.
1848	1	9	Usage guidelines
1848	1	10	Google is proud to partner with libraries to digitize public domain materials and make them widely accessible. Public domain books belong to the
1848	1	11	public and we are merely their custodians. Nevertheless, this work is expensive, so in order to keep providing this resource, we have taken steps to
1848	1	12	prevent abuse by commercial parties, including placing technical restrictions on automated querying.
1848	1	13	We also ask that you:
1848	1	14	+ Make non-commercial use of the files We designed Google Book Search for use by individual
1848	1	15	personal, non-commercial purposes.
1848	1	16	and we request that you use these files for
1848	1	17	+ Refrain from automated querying Do not send automated queries of any sort to Google’s system: If you are conducting research on machine
1848	1	18	translation, optical character recognition or other areas where access to a large amount of text is helpful, please contact us. We encourage the
1848	1	19	use of public domain materials for these purposes and may be able to help.
1848	1	20	+ Maintain attribution The Google “watermark” you see on each file is essential for informing people about this project and helping them find
1848	1	21	additional materials through Google Book Search. Please do not remove it.
1848	1	22	+ Keep it legal Whatever your use, remember that you are responsible for ensuring that what you are doing is legal. Do not assume that just
1848	1	23	because we believe a book is in the public domain for users in the United States, that the work is also in the public domain for users in other
1848	1	24	countries. Whether a book is still in copyright varies from country to country, and we can’t offer guidance on whether any specific use of
1848	1	25	any specific book is allowed. Please do not assume that a book’s appearance in Google Book Search means it can be used in any manner
1848	1	26	anywbhere in the world. Copyright infringement liability can be quite severe.

1848	1	63	gemeine Charakteristik) , 2. Geschichte der Apolo-
1848	1	64	getik, 3. Geschichte der einzelnen Dogmen. Die

1848	1	71	je nach dem grösseren oder geringeren Einfluss des-
1848	1	72	selben auf ihre Gestaltung die übrigen anzureihen,
1848	1	73	Jedenfalls würde an Charakteristik des Zeitab-
1848	1	74	schnitts gewonnen, was an Systematik verloren
1848	1	75	ginge. Die letztere gehört ja ohnehin der Dogma-
1848	1	76	tik und nicht der Geschichte an. Zwar hat es, wie

1848	1	20	Die Eintheilung und Anordnung sind in beiden Wer-

1848	1	35	Tode des Meisters, theilweise aufgegeben hat.
1848	1	36	Der Charakter einer Mineralogie spricht sich
1848	1	37	vornehmlich in der Behandlung der krystallographi-
1848	1	38	schen und der chemischen Kigenschaften der Mi-
1848	1	39	nerale aus. Zwar wird gewöhnlich noch eine dritte
1848	1	40	Klasse von Kigenschaften, nämlich die physischen,
1848	1	41	‚aufgeführt, aber diese haben eigentlich keine selbst-
1848	1	42	ständige Bedeutung, denn entweder gehören sie
1848	1	43	der ganzen Masse an, wie das specifische Gewicht,
1848	1	44	die mittlere Härte und Lichtbrechung, und sind
1848	1	45	eine Folge des chemischen Zustandes; oder sic hän-
1848	1	46	A. L. Z. 18480. KErster Band.

1848	1	30	derselben, und Jange nach dieser anhebt. IV. Ueber-
